ygData.subject: Re: [neat] 3D HyperNEAT Substrates
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Colin- There have been a few papers that have done things along these lines. In one paper, I actually compare HyperNEAT s performance on the same problem

Hi Colin-

There have been a few papers that have done things along these lines.

In one paper, I actually compare HyperNEAT's performance on the same problem
(evolving gaits for quadruped robots) with representations in 1D, 2D, and
3D. 

https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications/Clune-HyperNEATSensitivity
ToGeometry.pdf

Also, in my most recent paper, each node has x, y, and z coordinates. This
paper is similar to your suggestion because it is a visual problem, and we
needed to represent the pixels in a 2D plane. The problem is simpler than
what you probably envision, but the principle is the same:

https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications/Clune-ModularityInHyperNEA
T-Gecco2010.pdf

There have also been a number of papers that have inputs, hidden layers, and
outputs in their own 2D plane. All of my HyperNEAT papers take this
approach, although I usually have a separate output from the CPPN network
for each layer, instead of inputting a Z dimension (but you could do that
instead). You can find my papers at the link below, and Jason's checkers
papers also take this approach (available on the eplex page):

https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications.html

I also think the most recent multi-agent HyperNEAT paper has a Z dimension,
if I am remembering things correctly.

Finally, Ken has a discussion of the implications of different setups on the
HyperNEAT User's page FAQ, in the section titled " What is the right way to
set up a CPPN to encode a substrate with hidden nodes?". I think you'll find
that interesting. 

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html

Hope that helps.  


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
jclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune




> From: Colin <colin.green1@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 17 Apr 2010 22:31:43 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] 3D HyperNEAT Substrates
> 
> Hi,
> 
> Not sure if this has been discussed but I was thinking of implementing 3D
> substrates. The canonical HyperNEAT substrate I think is nodes arranged in
> layers of lines on the cartesian plane, with each row having a distinct
> position on the y-axis and the nodes within that row arranged along the
> x-axis. Hence the strength of a connection is a function of all four coords,
> weight = f(x1,y1,x2,y2).
> 
> Seems to me that many common tasks (such as processing image data) require
> each layer to be a plane, so we could have nodes in a plane occupying x/y axes
> and the planes/layers being distinguished by the z axis. weight =
> f(x1,y1,z1,x2,y2,z2) and the original 'flat' substrate can still be
> represented if necessary.
> 
> I'm intending to implement it like this - has anyone else implemented CPPNs
> this way? Are there any problems with this approach?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Colin.
> 
> 
>
